A potential problem is that debt forgiveness sets a precedent that similar loans in the future could also have the potential to be forgiven. For example, if a student's college debt is forgiven, it promotes accumulating more college debt later on. If loan debts are constantly being forgiven without consequence, some students may take advantage of it and spend money on non-school-related items instead of tuition. Appromimately $1 trillion of the current $1.2 trillion in student debt is in federal student loans, which means that US taxpayers are indeed paying for student loan debts rather than the students themselves. In the last 30 years, the cost attending a public four-year college has dramatically increased by an astounding 357 percent. This means that students are adding more debt to pay for college which set a type of continuing trend for other students to follow: get amnesty and you won't have to pay college loans. While student debt is a huge problem and amnesty programs are just allowing students to continue not paying off their college loans, there might be some positive things to letting the loans just "slide" so the students can enjoy their college experience without having to fork out their savings. No student wants to pay what money they have been saving up since they were in grade school on their education if they really want to spend that money on getting an apartment or renting a condo after they graduate college. Allowing for amnesty programs rids students of the stressful nights where they have to think about how they're going to eventually pay off their student debt, aside from studying for tests and paying gas and food bills. With amnesty programs, young adults are eased into the real"adult world" because they won't get slapped in the face with a huge debt right out of college. Sure, they will eventually have to pay off other debts but in the meantime it's a huge relief to be cut some slack, especially if students are being stressed out with the other components of their still maturing lives.

Some are saying that creating a new student amnesty program will result in students spending their money on other items rather than on their tuition, and because college would forgive a student's college debt, essentially more college debt will be accumulated because they would not have to pay for their tuition. Despite the good intentions of debt amnesty there is some concern about adverse effects. Debt forgiveness promotes the idea that other loans will also be forgiven, which promotes the accumulation of more debt. Additionally, most college debt belongs to the federal government, about $1 trillion of the current $1.2 trillion, so taxpayers would be forced to pay back this debt rather than students and their families. And finally, the price of college tuition has grown significantly, rising at 357% in the last 30 years, so the more debt is forgiven, the more money simply is not paid. Although it would be a great advantage to enact pardons on the student loan system, it is a fact that the colleges simply cannot afford to give these pardons. Those opposed to debt forgiveness may claim that the investment of taxpayer money in secondary educaiton is innapropriate- citing that students should be responsible for their debt in order to establish that financial responsibility is an immensely important skill. It is feared that the youth of America, if pardoned from their finiancial debt, will not partake in responsible spending habits and will continue to spend recklessly on items they should not be able to afford. However, while the approximate $1 trillion of student debt would require a significant amount of tax funds, an attempt to make education affordable, or at least to reduce the impact of the debt upon the student, would allow the student to better establish themselves in society before being overwhelmed by an onslaught of college debt; a system that has established and evidently benefitted the youth of the United Kingdom. In the United States, our current system of secondary education discourages disadvantaged or even middle-class youth from pursuing an education, and this unequal opprotunity created by the fear of formidable debt does not represent progressive, equitable values that are upheld by traditional American values. The $1 trillion in student debt is, indisputably, a more progressive and worthwhile contribution to the nation than other recipients of tax funds such as military equipment and foreign military occupancy, which represents over $13 trillion of US debt. Education, overall, is the strongest creator of equality and progressive action to American citizens, and should be protected and encouraged.

There will be more pros than cons if college students were given debt forgiveness. One of the major negative effects would be that college students won't have the responsibility of having to pay their debts; instead, they "spend money on frivolous items, not on tuition", notes one credible source. Since college students are just moved out and have a newfound freedom, they aren't going to be spending their money wisely-and that's when they have tuition to pay. Imagine if they didn't have to pay that $20,000 a year-they'd be going crazy with all that money! Giving college students debt forgiveness won't be a good idea because they won't spend the money properly. In addition, the colleges themselves will be is tremendous debt if they paid for their students' tuition. And who pays for this debt? The taxpayers do. According to another highly credible source "about $1 trillion of the current $1.2 trillion in student debt is in federal student loans/this means US taxpayers are paying for students' debt rather than students and families". This upsets many of the taxpayers because this money should be going to public projects that will benefit ALL of the community, not just a small portion of it. Some would say giving debt forgiveness is a great idea. They say it would promote more attending college. But it's not a good idea because more and more state debt would be accumulated.

Debt forgiveness ets precedent that similar loans in the future will also be forgotten. Furthermore, about $1 trillion of the current $1.2 trillion in student debt is in federal student loans. This means that US taxpayers are paying for students' debt rather than the students themselves. Clearly, debt forgivenss is an idea that cannot be carried out well.

While one may say that this is a potential problem--that debt forgiveness will only promote the accumulation of more college debt--the truth of the matter is that debt forgiveness will allow students to go into college without fear of the possibly detrimental money-loans. It has been assumed that forgiven loan debts result in students spending money on more "frivolous items" rather than tuition, however this presents a situation to test responisibility and give college students a window into the real world. YOUR CHILDREN ARE GETTING SO DEPRESSED ABOUT THE MONEY PROBLEMS THAT YOU GAVE US THAT WE ARE FORCED TO TAKE OUR OWN LIVES, BECAUSE WE CANT PAY THIS DEBT. with the debt problems you are giving us, we cant pay it off. it is nearly impossible, unless we get a job right out of college. While this program does have its merits, it also has several downsides. If the debt is forgiven as suggested by the program, it will set a precedent for incoming students, leading them to believe that their debt will be forgiven as well. This will cause them to spend even more money because they think they won't be held accountable for it. There is also a concern that the money that would have been used for tuition will then be used towards the purchase of frivolous items. Finally, there is the obvious concern of who will be paying for these forgiven loans. Currently, about $1 trillion of $1.2 trillion in student debt is in federal student loans, which means that US taxpayers are paying for students' debt. These taxpayers would be hit the hardest if the loans were forgiven, because taxes will have to continue to raise if this program is to remain sustainable.
Potential debt forgiveness sets precedent that similar loans in the future will also be forgiven.

However, there are quite a few potential problems that may occur when colleges forgive student debt. Within the last 20 years, the cost of public four-year college tuition has grown outrageously by 357 percent; this means that students will receive debt amnesty and won't have to pay for college loans. Another controversial argument is that when loan debts are forgiven, where do you think the students' tuition money is going to go? The answer is towards unnecessary, frivolous items. This student debt crisis won't be solved with a wave of a wand; anout $1 trillion of the current $1.2 trillion in student debt is in federal student loans; this means US tax payers are paying for students' debt instead of paying students and families. The biggest problem of all happens to be that when debt forgiveness takes it's toll, this sets precedent that similar loans in the future will also be forgiven. For example, forgiven college debt promotes accumulating more college debt.

These opponents claim that if students have their debt forgiven once, they may feel entitled to another debt forgiveness period in the future. This could lead to students becoming less responsible with their college funds and spending frivolously simply because they can. They also argue that much of that debt forgiveness would be coming out of the American taxpayer's pocket, due to the high percentage of student debt that is in federal loans. Opponents see a continuing trend of higher tuition leading to higher debt leading to more debt forgiveness, a cycle spiraling continuously downward. However, a simple solution would be to only forgive debt for high-performing students, encouraging good performance from the students. As long as colleges set limits on whose debt is forgiven, how much, and how often, this downward spiral proposed by the naysayers can be avoided.

Opponents of the proposal calling for debt forgiveness contend that giving students amnesty for college loans will have several adverse effects. The students who are forgiven of their debt would start to think that future debt would be paid off for them also. They start to accumulate more debt. Some students who have their debt forgiven would perhaps spend their money on frivolous items, not tution for their schooling. Of the $1.2 trillion in student debt $1 trillion of it is in federal student loans, which indicates that the US taxpayers are paying the students' debts rather than the student and their families. Students will not learn responsibility if they are set free of their loans.

The opposition states that there are multiple potential problems, two of which are the main basis of their arguments. They say that debt forgiveness promotes accumulating more debt, and that when they receive amnesty, it will also promote frivolity and the students will spend money on things other than their tuition. These would be valid, and very persuasive, points if it were true that students are the ones who pay off most of their debt. However, out of the current student debt of $1.2 trillion, $1 trillion of it is in federal student loans. That means that U.S. taxpayer dollars are paying for the majority of debt students accumulate. Also, if the students are required to pay off their debts, they will only dig themselves deeper into debt. In the last 30 years, the average cost of tuition for a public 4-year institution has grown by 357 percent, this means that the students accumalative debt will only compound if they are forced to pay it. They are then left with a continuing trend of debt that lasts much longer than college and affects their whole lives. If, however, they are given amnesty on their debts, they remain to live debt free and accomplish the great goal of the American dream.

Opponents of the proposal calling for debt forgiveness contend that giving students amnesty for college loans will have several adverse effects. Not to mention, allowing debt forgiveness may give students now and in the future a false understanding that any debt will be forgiven and cause them to accumulate even more college debt. These two problems outline the major problem of the direct effects of the debt forgiveness program, and are especially reasonable given the age of college students and their general desire to be careless or impractical in some of their decisions. Of course, this is not the case for all college students, but it is an observed trend among them.

A student debit crisis has cause much concern, not only to those who owe the debt, the students and their parents, but also to everyone who depends on a strong, viable US economy. Economists and jobs analysts consistently observe that higher education is "still the best investment" a young person can make in his or her future. The demand among expanding companies is for more job candidates with college degrees, so naturally, more people are turning to higher education to get an edge in a tough job market. For the sake of our economy, we need to make a college affordable to more young people trying to enter the work force, and to do this, we need to address the problem of college debt. Our local college's proposal to forgive the debt of currently enrolled students who have grade-point averages of over 2.5 is an effective strategy for solving this student debt problem.
